channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SPR-406] JSF-Spring 2.6 incompatible with current CVS head
item.description:
This is sandbox code I believe...

From the forums:
http://forum.springframework.org/viewtopic.php?t=1388

Hi,

I've just freshed my local Spring source and find that JSF-Spring won't compile. The problems are in the FacesSpringVariableResolver:

1. the transformedBeanName method of the super class has been turned to private, thus not accessible the the subclass.
2. isFactoryDereference has seemed to be factored out to the BeanFactoryUtils. (This is trivial to fix though)

I'm wondering if the future version of the AbstractBeanFactory.transformedBeanName can still keep its protected signature.

Any ideas?

Thanks!

Bing Ran

to follow up,

I also had to modify the getPropertyValue method in the FacesConfigXmlBeanDefinitionParser class in the JSF-Spring package to make them work together:

Here is the change I needed to make:

from:

return new RuntimeBeanReference(value);

to:

return new RuntimeBeanReference(value.substring(2, value.indexOf("}")));
item.summary: JSF-Spring 2.6 incompatible with current CVS head

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Thanks for reporting this - I've just re-added the protected versions of isFactoryDereference and transformedBeanName.

However, I don't see the cause of the FacesConfigXmlBeanDefinitionParser parser issue. Does this work against Spring 1.1.1 but not against CVS head? Could you raise this with the JSF-Spring guys?

Juergen

Thanks Colin for putting this in the Jira. I was not subscribing to the SCM list so I was not notified of this, and thanks Juergen to make the code change.

Since I felt I had a good command of JSF (SUN RI) I decided to see how hard it would be to port the JPetStore in the Spring distribution to using JSF as the web tier, with the help of the JSF-Spring code.

I was a month ago the last time I tested out the JSF-Spring code and it seemed to work for most of it. Then I found the couple of issues with the latest Spring head.

The one that really puzzled me was the this method in the faces config bean def reader:

private Object getPropertyValue(String beanName, Element element) {
String value = textValue(element, beanName).trim();
if (value.startsWith("#

{") && value.endsWith("}

"))
return new RuntimeBeanReference(value);
return value;
}
}

for a bean reference such as in:

<managed-property>
<property-name>managedPropertyBean</property-name>
<value>#

{managedPropertyAccessBean}

</value>
</managed-property>
<managed-property>

the whole string, including the #{ } was passed to being searched for a matching bean def in another context xml, where the bean is defed without the leading and trailing curlies. That's why removing them seemed to solved the issue. And this code seemed to work fine just a while ago. Just wondering how could it possibly...

I was hoping the original author of the code could spot my post, since the mailing list in the sourceforge had a similar issue reported but did not get any attention.

Other than that, my porting effort has been quite been smooth for one night's effort (all hand coding, no JSF IDE). Not much surprise so far. Everything worked as advertised. I keep using all the old service tier code and configuration files for service tier and DAO tier. The petstore service facade was able to hook up to the JSF backing beans easily in a declarative manner. The part that needs major rework will probably be the security part.

I hope JSF with Spring will prove to be a very viable tech stack.

OK, so I consider this resolved for the time being. Any issues in FacesConfigXmlBeanDefinitionReader need to be resolved in the JSF-Spring code, not in the Spring core.

Juergen
